dialogues.speaker: INT. DARK ROOM. THE PAST. DAY
dialogues.text: In darkness, chemicals wash over a copper plate. Strange silvery patterns evolve in the half-light.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. TERRA DEL FUEGO. DAY
dialogues.text: Our POV rotates downwards onto an irregular shape. This shape is grey-green and crammed with detail which emerges as we draw close - like a continent seen from out space. A fruit fly lands on it and we now recognise the shape as patch of lichen. A number of other fruit flies are grazing there. Wider. The lichen is on a rock. A   black lizard climbs o the horizon - stalking flies. A slow advance. A sudden rush. A fly is snapped up and mashed between toothless gums. The lizard is fixing its beady gaze on the next potential victim when... A shadow falls, the lizard tries to flee. A seabird grabs the lizard in its claws. Death is sudden and bloody. The bird settles to eat. Whizz...Thunk. A sharpened stick flies out of nowhere and impales the bird through its wing. The wounded bird falls between boulders, flapping helplessly. The rest of the flock take to their air, calling and wheeling as... A crowd of local savages come racing over the larger horizon of the rocks armed with primitive bows and arrows spears, rocks and throwing-sticks... A child grabs the injured bird and kills it. An adult biffs the child on the head and steals the bird. The rest of the savages leap among the jagged rocks smiti each other, shouting and snarling among the whirling floc of birds.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. COASTLINE. DAY
dialogues.text: A POV shot through a telescope: The whirling birds the strange half-animal forms of the savages. The whole scene is jerky, out of focus and inaudible at this great distance like a very old silent movie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In Terra del Fuego. The "land of fire" - A blighted and loveless country on the earths furthest rim - there lives a community of the dirtiest, the rudest, the least civilised beings you can imagine. The telescope focusses. The image becomes a little cleare

dialogues.speaker: EXT. CLIFF TOP. DAY
dialogues.text: The flock of boobies fly out to sea. The savages follow as far as the top of the cliffs, where they stop in sudden amazement, staring at a distant saili ship.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They were all completely naked, the men as well as the women, with hair down to their bottoms. They spoke in grunts and they never washed their hands and faces! In many respects they resembled wild animals, except that animals are kinder to their children. A savage child makes a comment and gets biffed on the hea again. Strange, foreign cries of the sailors are faintly audible over the water, as the anchor is dropped with a rattle an a splash. A small boat is lowered.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One day, Captain Fitzroy went ashore to meet them. The slow rhythm of the oars. Sailors and savages clutch their weapons, watching each other in breathless anticipation. 5   INT. DAGUERROTYPE STUDIO. THE PAST. DAY. A door opens and a figure in black, hurries past, clutchi a number of prepared photographic plates in their light proof cases.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not long now. I shall be with you immediately... ANNIE DARWIN, wearing in a checkered dress, aged about 9 years old, sits looking straight at camera. She has short hair and a pretty oval face On her lap there is a posy of artificial flowers, in the background an improbable vista of jagged mountain.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ready now. Very still please.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will this hurt, papa?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. It is only a beam of light.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How can light make a picture.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well they prepare a copper plate with chemicals on it. The chemicals are sort of energized by the light reflecting off your face. Then silver sticks onto the plate according to where the light is brightest.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Betty was worried it would hurt. ....What a little duck she is.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So as I was saying, Captain Fitzroy went ashore to interview the Fuegans....

dialogues.speaker: EXT. SHORE. TIERRA DEL FUEGO. DAY
dialogues.text: Waves lap on the black pebbly beach, where a young naval captain FITZROY with mutton chop sideboards disembarks lightly from his jolly-boat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: After some discussion persuaded three of the savages` children to come home with him. The "discussion" is more in the nature of heated bargaini for slaves. Fitzroy finally produces enough cloth and axe-heads to secure the deal. The unwilling children pushed away by their parents and grabbed by sailors who bundle them, biting crying and kicking, into the waiting boat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Their names were Jemmy Buttons, York Minster and Fuegia Basket. 7   INT. BELOW DECKS. DAY. Below decks: a slapstick struggle with soap and scrubbing brushes - much biting kicking and howling - as sailors scrub the children clean.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ow! Shite! Hold still ye maggot!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The captain had them washed and got their hair cut, then dressed them in proper clothes, and taught them proper table manners.

dialogues.speaker: INT. CAPTAIN'S CABIN. DAY
dialogues.text: The children, cleaned and dressed,   seem happy enough in their new situation. They sit at the captain's table clumsily sawing with a knife and chasing Brussel sprouts around a plate with the cutlery. A sprout shoots off the table

dialogues.speaker: EXT. SHIP'S DECK. DAY
dialogues.text: Splosh! A weighted canvas body bag is tipped overboard. The rough unshaven seamen crew all remove their hats, som of them cry openly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: York Minster died of the smallpox but the other two learned English and went to meet the queen.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. BUCKINGHAM PALACE. DAY
dialogues.text: A fanfare as the gates swing open as a coach-and-four rattles through.

dialogues.speaker: INT. BUCKINGHAM PALACE. DAY
dialogues.text: Jemmy Buttons, looking very smart in velvet suit with silver buttons gives proper bow and shakes the Royal hand Fuegia Basket curtsies. Queen Victoria remains out of shot but her attendants han out presents off a purple silk cushion: A Bible for Fuegi and a telescope for Jemmy 12   EXT. SHORE OF TIERRA DEL FUEGO. DAY. Hairy savages reassemble on the cliff tops

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two years later. Captain Fitzroy and I took them back, in the company of a young Parson, hoping they would bring the other savages to god and to teach the others by example. The hairy savages squint from the cliffs to sea.... Another boat, the Beagle, has anchored in their bay. Captain Fitzroy is being rowed ashore with Darwin, plus a very young parson and the two young Fuegans, who are happ and agitated to see their homeland again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And what do you think happened? 13   INT. DAGUERROTYPE STUDIO. THE PAST. DAY. Annie suspects there is a joke coming and cant help her mouth from twitching the corners.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (laughing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Correct! A complete and total failure!

dialogues.speaker: EXT. ROCKY CREVICES. TERRA DEL FUEGO. DAY
dialogues.text: At the first sight of their countrymen, Jemmy and Fuegia rip off their clothes, drop the bible and the telescope, and run to join them, yelling like nut-cases.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yaah!! Yahh!! The benighted young parson scrambles after them, collecti their discarded garments from among the rain-swept rocks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jemmy! Fuegia The telescope is smashed. The Bible lies abandoned - the wind catching its soggy pages and whirling them off in th storm. 15   INT. DAGUERROTYPE STUDIO. DAY. Darwin still laughing, dabs his eyes

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (laughing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yaaah! The photographer disappears behind black curtains.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Very still now. No more talking please Annie composes her face in an expression of angelic seriousness. A glass dome above her head glows snapdragon blue Close on Darwin watching his daughter, his eyes still dam with tears of laughter. Electricity hums. The strange blue light glows brighter, brighter... Brighter. The image of his daughter imprints on Darwin's memory. Ju so. Forever. 16   INT. DOWN HOUSE. DINING ROOM. THE PRESENT. EVENING. Servants are laying a table for dinner Gas lamps and the coal fire struggle to illuminate the lofty room. Mrs Davies the Welsh cook, bangs the dinner gong and shou across the darkening garden outside. MR DAVIES (O.S.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Children! Franky! Horace! Dinner! Darwins attractive wife Emma adjusts the lamps and the bo run in, Franky aged 10 Lenny aged 8 Horace aged 6. LENNY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mama mama. EMMA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. What is it LENNY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Horace says he's six feet tall. EMMA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have you all washed your hands. HORACE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He said I have to be or I can't join the army. EMMA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: First things first. An officer must always tuck his shirt in. Their elder sisters Betty and Etty take their places at table BETTY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The boys made a camp with a camp- fire LENNY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh! Sneak! EMMA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where's the campfire. BETTY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the summer house but Brodie put it out. Parslow enters with the turreen EMMA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank-you Parslow. Where is Mr Darwin? PARSLOW

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He was killing pigeons Ma'am EMMA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will everybody sit down please. As they are pulling in their chairs, Darwin enters, dryin his hands on his trousers. He's aged ten years since we last saw him and has lost hi former air of gaiety. He sits, with a distracted nod to the family. PARSLOW

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Soup du jour, sir The children smile at Parslow's air of earnest formality but the atmosphere even among the younger kids is sombre and subdued. DARWIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you Parslow He butters some bread and starts eating. Emma clears her throat. DARWIN.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh. The children bow their heads. The bread stick in darwins mouth. Emma says grace. EMMA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lord God who watches over all that we do. Bless this family and the food we eat. In Jesus name. Amen. Everyone repeats the "Amen" except Darwin. EMMA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I hear Mr Hooker is coming tomorrow. The children prick up their ears at this. They like Hooke DARWIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He won't stay long. EMMA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did he say what it was about? DARWIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think this is not the time to discuss it. EMMA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe the time to discuss it was before you invited him. DARWIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He sent a telegram. I'm sorry if it inconveniences you. Emma purses her lips and turns her attention back to the children

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eat your soup now. Darwin takes a couple of spoonfuls, pauses, as a wave of nausea sweeps over him, then pushes away the dish.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (To Parslow)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell Mr Davies it was delicious, but my stomach is not quite right yet. (To Emma)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Excuse me. He gets up and leaves. As soon as he has gone, the childr natural talkativeness reasserts itself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can we take Mr Hooker to the Chalk pits. Why can't he stay. Can we pick blackberries?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think he is just here to work 17   EXT. DOWN HOUSE. DARWIN'S STUDY. THE PRESENT. NIGHT. A branch taps gently against the window pain, like an insistent guest demanding to be admitted. The coal fire burns low in the grate - wind in the chimne rattling the damper Firelight flickers on a collection of finches in a glass case, on a bird skeleton, on a fossil, and on numerous specimen bottles containing the fleshy parts of barnacles preserved in spirit-of-wine. Darwin sits immobile in his chair, regarding a locked, black lacquered steel trunk, on the floor under his work table. A voice speaks behind him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aren't you going to open it? He turns and sees her sitting on the day bed - the same little bright eyed girl from the daguerrotype studio. She's the same age as she was then and wearing the same checkered dress - though Darwin himself has aged ten year

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe best if I just burn the whole lot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (horrified)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No papa - You can't. I'm in it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't be absurd. Of course you're not.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The story of me when I was small. You showed me the pages.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ah yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "The natural History of babies" ...Remember?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course I remember. He continues to stare at the shiny black box, his hand fluttering lightly - a nervous tic. Music seeps in - a soothing Chopin Nocturne and....

dialogues.speaker: INT. DOWN HOUSE DRAWING ROOM. THE PAST. NIGHT
dialogues.text: Darwin aged 40 - bright-eyed and inquisitive leans over t examine something, offering it his finger tip while makin little tut tut tut noises. In the cot is a one-month old baby.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Annie. Annie. Annie. The piano music continuing over, as her fist closes round the end of his finger, then tries to pull it towards her mouth. He pulls it away from her and she frowns. He offers it again and the tug of war becomes a game. Baby Annie laughs. Darwin writes something in his notebook. Then tucks his pencil behind his ear and tries out various facial expressions - scowling, smiling - to gauge the baby's response. Emma turns on the piano-stool.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (affectionately)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you doing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just playing. She comes over and, leaning against him, reads from his notebook.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Six weeks: Gurgles. Holds tight to my finger. Tries to suck. Smiles at my smile" The baby lets out a long yodel of pleasure

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I should add that she is musical.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I hope you do not plan to treat all our children as little animacules to be included in your experiments.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you mean there will be more.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I assumed that's what you wanted. Of course, if the idea doesn't appeal then...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Appeal? Dearest cousin. I am making plans for an army! He takes Emma in his arms. She gives a little squeak - caught off balance then laughing as he waltzes her around the room, singing.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. WOODS AND MEADOW. THE PAST. DAY
dialogues.text: An army of children - the Darwin family - run across the screen from left to right. The little kids first, scampering through the hay meadow off into the trees. Household servants follow, carrying blankets, hampers and parasols. The red haired Scottish nursemaid Brodie, shouts ahead to the little ones.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Careful! Not too far ahead now. The children ignore her so she pick up her skirts and rac after them. The Adults follow in their wake - Charles and Emma Darwin plus two younger men aged about 30 - Joe Hooker and the R Innes

dialogues.speaker: EXT. RIVER BANK. THE PAST. DAY
dialogues.text: They have set up their picnic on a river bank. Emma is reading. Joseph Hooker is teaching the boys to fish. He has spectacles and long wispy side-whiskers: a battered panam on his head and his trousers rolled up to his knees.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Give it time to take a bite. The fishing float moves a little

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's Nibbling. Nibbling. Oh Bother. No-one move. He's dropped his spectacles in the shallows. George (aged 5) feels a jerk on the line. He squeals and drops the rod. The fish takes off upriver. Will goes afte the dropped rod. On shore, Annie runs up with a collecting box to show her father

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've got one. She opens the box to show him a little black beetle. The local parson, Innes, inclines his head to inspect it

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What should I feed it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A leaf I should think. What plant did you find him on?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the mud under that log. Innes looks to Darwin for advice MR INNES

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Or a piece of bark maybe. Darwin peers at the insect DARWIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cycrus caraboides. You can see from the mandibles he's a hunter. He feeds on slugs and snails. INNES

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh. Annie runs off, calling to the other children ANNIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Etty! Willy! Find me some slugs. He's hungry! INNES

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When I said I knew something of insects..... DARWIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh tush.... I studied Theology for a year but yet I know exceedingly little of the bible. INNES

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then once I am properly installed at Down I shall take pleasure in instructing you. DARWIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I should look forward to that immensely. Emma, knowing her husband's ambivalence towards religion, casts him a slightly arch, amused look. Innes notices thi though he pretends not to. Hooker returns from the river, looking slightly damp, wit the rod which he has managed to retrieve HOOKER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everyone's a bit wet. Sorry, but the fish are surely biting. More worms, boys, more worms. George is looking under stones HOOKER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Try over there, Georgey, we've used all these ones up. They move off, joining Annie and the other in their hunt for crawling things. The air above them is heavy and sparkling with pollen.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. OCEAN. NIGHT
dialogues.text: A sailing ship sails past, trailing phosphorescence it it wake.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On the Beagle, quite, often we would drop a flask in the ocean and find it teeming with living particles which glowed in the night

dialogues.speaker: INT. SHIP'S CABIN. NIGHT
dialogues.text: The figure in silhouette of young Darwin inspects a flask of sea water, glowing in the darkness. He takes a few drops on a watch glass and places them on the illuminated stage of his microscope. Under the microscope, against a black background, million of tiny swimming animals.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. BY THE RIVER BANK. THE PAST. DAY
dialogues.text: Cut to the air above the picnickers - alive with glitteri particles - against the dark trees behind.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ....so much beauty for so little purpose.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Surely not without purpose. They were helping to light the ship's way were they not. Darwin smiles at the idea, turns to Innes

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you familiar with the works of Thomas Malthus, Mr Innes?.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He married his first cousin didn't he?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So did Charles.... So did I.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, I was not at all suggesting.... Emma waves it away. Just teasing DARWIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He made the point that if every trout, say, has a hundred offspring And so on and so on through the generations. Then the planet would be knee deep in trout in just a few decades. INNES

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course most of the eggs are destroyed and eaten so the numbers remain stable. That is the beauty of God's plan. Emma gives Darwin a "So there" look and hands Innes a sandwich. EMMA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cheese and cucumber INNES

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank-you Somewhere in the woods, Annie has found a treasure trove worms and slugs. ANNIE (O.S. DISTANT)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Over here ....there are millions! DARWIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It doesn't strike you as an exceedingly wasteful plan - these myriad lives created only to be immediately extinguished. EMMA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a gentle warning) Charles.... INNES

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (confidently) They are providing food for others. DARWIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You think they are happy about it? INNES

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Happy? Close up on a writing worm. Hooker is instructing George how to put a worm on a hook. HOOKER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Through his bottom and up though his mouth - perfect DARWIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ....To be doing Gods will. EMMA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Innes) Please ignore him. After two glasses of claret he tends to becomes mischievous. DARWIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No I'm serious. If thousands are destroyed that a few may live their lives, is not the general sum total of happiness not in some kind of massive deficit? INNES

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well far be it from me to speculate on the mind of God, far less the happiness of an earthworm ha ha ha. But it seems to me that nature is at peace...and most of her denizens are content. EMMA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Amen. INNES

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Darwin) You don't agree. DARWIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think it is a battlefield. A constant and shifting struggle for survival between everything and everything else. EMMA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I really do think men have a problem with natural beauty. They cannot ever just accept it for what it is. (Calls off) Children! Sandwiches! (Then) Tell me of your wife Mr Innes. Darwin lies back on the rug and turns his head away from the sun. The base of a tangled hedgerow is just a few feet away. Looking into its tangled depths he sees something gleamin white - the skull of a sheep with briars growing through the eye sockets.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. BASE OF THE HEDGEROW. TIME-LAPSE. NIGHT
dialogues.text: The sheep's skull is half-decomposed. In fast forward we see maggots pecking the remnants of flesh from the bone, birds feeding on the maggots. A bird becomes trapped among the briars. It flaps madly upsetting a nest. Eggs and blind featherless hatchlings fall down through t dark web of branches where they are devoured by voles and rats, then slugs, then worms All the times tendrils and vines are growing, the skull - bleached white - now encased in a cage of thick spiny branches, fizzing with insect life, where ants and ground beetles feast on the carcasses of slugs and....

dialogues.speaker: INT. DARWIN'S BEDROOM. THE PRESENT. DAWN
dialogues.text: Darwin wakes in sudden terror. Dawn light illuminates the wallpaper in front of him - a William Morris design of interweaving vines. Emma, is asleep in her night-cap at his side. Darwin lies for a while in the semi darkness, until his hand, fluttering on the coverlet, becomes still at last. 26   INT. SCULLERY. THE PAST. DAY. Light and noise. Crash of gleaming copperware, clattering of water in the pipes as the servants prepare Sunday breakfast The cook, Mrs Davies looks out through a steamed up windo to see the angular figure of Charles Darwin, bent almost double inspecting a tiny segment of lawn. Brodie joins Mrs Davies at the window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is he doing now, exactly?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cutting the grass with nail scissors.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Such a shame he never had a proper job. At least your Mr Thackeray had his books to write.

dialogues.speaker: INT. DOWN HOUSE. THE PAST. DAY
dialogues.text: Children thunder up and down the stairs between Brodie wh is doing a final check on grooming and Emma who is marshalling them in the hall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chop chop Georgie. Socks! And you have not buttoned your trousers. Baby Lenny starts crying and she goes to comfort him 29   INT. GIRLS' BEDROOM. THE PAST. DAY. Brodie is arranging hair and tying ribbons for Annie (9) Etty (6) and Betty (3)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you never think of getting married Miss Brodie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Once. But he went to Australia and I missed my chance. Willy passes the door, his hair in need of brushing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Master William. Hairbrush. William comes in. Brodie brushes the back of his hair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ow. Ow!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well what do you expect. It is a birds nest.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Papa says God doesn't care if we are neat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (brushing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your father is a very wize man but has a small understanding of religion. No-one can read what goes down in Gods great book of accounts. ....Fingernails. Willy presents them for checking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can go. 30   INT. HALLWAY. THE PAST. DAY. The children come racing and swinging and clattering down the stairs. Emma, holding the baby in one arm, steers a tricycle out the way, clearing a path to the door

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs Davies, Will you ask Jenny to wear a bonnet. I would not like people to think her fast. George aged 5 tugs at her skirt

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can I bring my mouse for a blessing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What mouse? George (5) pulls it out from his pocket. Its dead, muddy and bloody

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Elsie caught it in the barn. We need to pray for his soul

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mice don't have souls. Leave it on the window sill. Everyone come now or we shall be late.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. LANEWAY. DOWN HOUSE. THE PAST. DAY
dialogues.text: Pealing of church bells Mist rises from the ploughed fields and hangs among the ancient oaks. A little procession heads down the lane. The Darwins - Charles and Emma - plus their servants and children (olde now, for we have flipped into the present), all in their Sunday best. The trees are bare. Their breath condenses as they walk.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. VILLAGE SQUARE. THE PRESENT. DAY
dialogues.text: The ancient flint church stands in the centre of Downe (sic) village, opposite the George and Dragon pub. A massive and venerable Yew tree casts its shade over a number of gravestones one of them inscribed "to Mary Darw born Sept 1842 died Oct 1842." Beyond the church fence, villagers greet each other befor heading inside. The great majority of the village have turned out, from Squire Lubbock through the tradesmen and domestic servants from the village to the clodhoppers (fa labourers) in their colored smocks. Rev Innes is welcoming his large flock at the gate.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Reverend Innes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smiling)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ma'am. Welcome. Welcome Then his eye moves on to Charles Darwin and his smile falters, his expression turning slightly cold. Darwin tips his hat rather stiffly and walks away, throug the throng of parishioners, leaving his family to file in the church without him.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. WOODLAND. PRESENT. DAY
dialogues.text: Darwin walks across the meadow and into the woods. A flock of crows take flight from the rookery in the bare trees overhead.

dialogues.speaker: INT. DOVECOTE. PRESENT. DAY
dialogues.text: In darkness, a furious struggle, squawking and franticall beating wings. Darwin seizes on a dove and backs out of the dovecote, th silhouette of his upper torso taking shape in the square hole in the floor. He climbs down the ladder, passes the captive bird down t Parslow, then climbs back up and pushes him upper body in the dovecot again, in search of the next victim.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. THE GARDEN. DOWN HOUSE. THE PRESENT. DAY
dialogues.text: The dovecote is a substantial affair on four pillars with ladder in the centre. Outside the dovecote, the boys are racing around playing soldiers. (Franky 10, Lenny 8, Horace 6) Parslow has a number of the birds in cages

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ring the two milky pouters. We'll sacrifice the tumblers and skeletonize them. Then... He looks up as a coach appears in the lane. The boys immediately break off from their game and run after it, shouting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's Mr Hooker. It's Mr Hooker! Darwin tries to wipe the bird shit off his hands and succeeds only in getting it on his sleeve. His breathing quickens. He seems at a loss. Parslow is awaiting further instructions

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then... what Sir?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just. ...to the shed with them. I shall clean myself up. He hurries off. 36   EXT. THE FRONT GATE. THE PRESENT. DAY. The coach pulls up and Hooker alights - ten years older than when we saw him catching fish, but still with the sa hallmark side whiskers and wire-rimmed spectacles, the sa springy step and ready grin. Already he is being mobbed by the younger boys - Lenny, Franky, and Horace - who clearly adore him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: - We're the Light Brigade Horace is a Russian.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good choice Horace. I shall be Lord Raglan and watch the slaughter from a safe distance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: - Will you give us a piggy-back? - Lenny cut his foot on a nail. There was lots of blood! Emma emerges from the front door. She smiles, pleased to see Hooker despite her misgivings. Then her smile falters as another man emerges from the coach behind him. HOOKER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Emma. Forgive the short notice. You know Thomas Huxley. EMMA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Only by reputation HUXLEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs Darwin. HOOKER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He insisted on coming and I could not refuse him. EMMA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell papa his visitors are here. LENNY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He knows already. HORACE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He went that way. Emma smiles brightly, covering for her embarrassment at h husband's increasingly erratic behavior. EMMA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anyway. Come in please. Come in. Hooker heads towards the house, the boy still clustered around him. FRANKY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sir, Is it true when you were in the Himalayas you were imprisoned by the king of Sikkim? HOOKER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Absolutely true. LENNY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And he thought you were a spy for stealing his rhododendrons? HOOKER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's approximately true. FRANKY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ....and he wouldn't let you leave unless you agreed to marry his fattest daughter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. (Conspiratorial) ....but you are never to tell my wife that!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Children leave Mr Hooker alone now. I'm sure he has more important things to discuss.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not really, but I think Mr Huxley does.... Huxley has seen Darwin, washing his hands by the "skeletonizing shed". Huxley hangs back to introduce himself as Hooker steers Emma off into the house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have my heart set on a cup of tea and one of Mrs Davies' scones. Emma looks anxiously after Huxley but allows herself to b gently side-lined. 37   INT. KITCHEN. THE PRESENT. DAY . Emma is by the kitchen window, rearranging tea things on tray. The sky outside is dark and lowering. Through the window she can see Darwin heading off down th sand walk - head bowed, walking stick in hand - deep in conversation with Huxley. She drops a tea-cup which smashes on the stone floor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll do that ma'am. Please. Let me do it. 38   EXT. DOWN HOUSE. THE SAND WALK. THE PRESENT. DAY. The Sand-walk is a gravel walking path between the garden and the fields, flanked by mature oaks and ancient willow

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're reforming the Linnean. The committee will comprise myself, Lyell, Huxley...yourself of course if you are willing. Darwin grunts noncommittally. The Crunch crunch of their feet is punctuated by the regular stomp of his metal-shod walking stick. HUXLEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We intend to reclaim science as a profession - wrest it away from the country parsons and beetle- collectors. Your book will be our rallying point. DARWIN.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know it is not yet any fit state to publish. HUXLEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have read your detailed abstract. The argument is complete and utterly compelling. All that is lacking is the detail and we know you have that in abundance. Your barnacle work has established you as the pre- eminent authority on marine life. DARWIN.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On one small mollusc! HOOKER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In which the whole story of creation can be read. Do not pretend to me that was not your intention. DARWIN.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Honestly.... HUXLEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A "family tree" of barnacles stretching back 300 million years to the time it was a free swimming prawn!. DARWIN.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There are many gaps. HOOKER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course with gaps! But that is the very point. If we but had the complete fossil record we could trace all life back to one speck of protoplasm. The branching of forms in ever more complex succession...until. DARWIN.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes yes, but one cannot infer too much. HOOKER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr Darwin. Either you are being disingenuous or you do not fully understand you own accomplishment. You have killed God. DARWIN.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr Huxley HUXLEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ....and good riddance to the bearded malicious old bugger! DARWIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (interrupts) Please I must beg of you.... HUXLEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. I must beg of you sir. Joseph Hooker we know is too nice a chap to do it. You are a fine and brilliant man who hates to give offence - an admirable quality - wish I had it myself. But what do we believe? What do we know to be true. Will you light the way or leave us all to flounder in the mire for another decade. He stops and lowers himself onto a bench, teeth clenched. HOOKER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you alright? DARWIN.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A touch of indigestion. It will pass. Its clearly worse than that, but Huxley, refusing to be distracted, blithely ignores it and sits down beside him til the worst of it passes. HUXLEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is time to write your book Mr Darwin. Write it brilliantly as we all know you can. Strike hard and fast with a blow that is utterly conclusive. DARWIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (in pain) Sir, you are talking like a revolutionary and really... HUXLEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is a revolution. And not before time. (MORE) HUXLEY (cont'd)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Goodbye to the lot of em - damned bishops and Archbishops with their threats of eternal punishment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And you'd replace Gods Laws with what.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The laws of logic. The laws of nature.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Knowing, as we do, that most capital crimes are her everyday practises: Theft, rape, murder, adultery, infanticide.... Huxley waves it away

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We live in a society bound together by the church. An improbable sort of barque I grant you but at least it floats. You suggest we change all that at a stroke. You wish me to rebuild, plank by plank, the very vessel we are sailing in. 39   EXT. DOWN HOUSE. DAY. The Coach to London has pulled up outside the front gate. Huxley is aboard. Darwin is talking with the coachman Hooker comes down the path in his black coat, carrying hi Gladstone bag.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr Hooker. He turns. He has already said his good-byes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I beg you, please don't push him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No-one can push Charles. You know how fixed he is. Bit of a barnacle himself ... his own words.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And if you prize him from his rock he will die. I know you all mean well but....

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Impatiently)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All aboard! Hooker gets aboard. Huxley leans out of a window and wave cheerily to the whey-faced Darwin

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We'll meet again, Mr Darwin

dialogues.speaker: INT. THE LANEWAY. DAY
dialogues.text: The coach pulls away. Looking back though the rear window Hooker sees Emma with the boys clustered around her skirts.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What did she say to you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That it was killing him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A mighty slow death considering the time he's spent. We'll be dead and buried ourselves if he prevaricates much longer. Huxley takes off his spectacles and polishes them, embarrassed by Huxley's directness, inspecting his own conscience in the bevelled glass.

dialogues.speaker: INT. DARWIN'S STUDY. NIGHT
dialogues.text: In the darkened study, with his specimens and books all around him, Darwin kneels by the box. Steeling himself, he unlocks the padlock and opens the li and takes out the papers and notebooks which are stored there. The bulk of it is a single manuscript, accumulated over many years, divided into 14 chapters with pages of notes interleaved. The Chapters are headed. Variation under domestication, variation under nature, Struggle for Existence, Natural Selection.... A noise behind him almost makes him jump out of his skin. Its Annie, ten years old in her checked dress, as she wil always be in his imagination.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why are you scared?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Like you said. You're in it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Its only a book, silly. He sits there regarding the open box, paralysed by indecision. Annie tenderly smooths his hair, rearranging his collar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you doing, Annie?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm making you beautiful.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have to work. Though the soft touch of her little hands is almost too real for him to bear and he closes his eyes

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Breath in, papa. Breathe out. Now Tell me a story.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have no time....

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: About Jenny. Please? The sound of a wave breaking. Wind stirs Darwin's hair He opens his eyes and he is ....

dialogues.speaker: EXT. ENGLISH BEACHSIDE. THE PAST DAY
dialogues.text: Sitting with Annie ten years ago on an English pebble beach. She has collected a pile of shells and is arranging them "families". The dialogue is continuous

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why do you always ask for Jenny? Its so sad.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's why I like it. It makes me cry. She looks up from her shells and smiles winningly. Darwin looks out to sea, at the bright crashing line of surf, and begins the familiar, much-told tale:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Once apon a time there was a family of Orang-u-tangs living in the jungles of darkest Borneo

dialogues.speaker: EXT. JUNGLES OF BORNEO. DAY
dialogues.text: Our POV moves between dark tropical trees to find a group of Orangutans flopping around grooming each other. As with the land of the Fuegan savages, there is somethin slightly artificial about these jungles, as though the trees really belong in Kew gardens, and the naked jungle warriors, whom we now see stalking through them, are on loan from the museum of mankind.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Their eldest daughter was the most loving, caring and trusting Orang of all. We follow a young nimble female, swinging through the trees, revelling in her own gymnastic ability, until she stops - hearing something: the sound of human speech.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But these qualities in themselves cannot guarantee an ape's survival. Sometimes, quite the reverse. Native hunters are creeping through the undergrowth A warning screech from one of the Orang-u-tangs posted as lookouts. Most of the apes flee up into the canopy. Jenny stays whe she is, fascinated, just a moment longer than is prudent.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When she realized her danger it was too late. As she turns to flee a weighted net is thrown on top of her. The hunters pounce.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They put her in a bag and carried her off....

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: " much to her loving parent's sorrow."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Exactly. The family screech and hoot, anguished, as the hunters he back off through the trees.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. MARKET-PLACE. DAY
dialogues.text: Exotic coins and bank-notes pass from hand to hand: from the tribal chief to the sultan, in his overlarge turban, from the sultan to the trader in his solar topee and stained white suit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The hunters sold her the to the Sultan who promptly sold her to a visiting Englishman who packed her aboard a sailing ship and brought her to London zoo. Jenny is taken out of a bamboo cage and put into a metal cage.

dialogues.speaker: INT. CARGO SHIP. DAY
dialogues.text: The cage is lowered by a crane. Jenny looks out from her swaying prison at spinning grey skies and brick warehouse

dialogues.speaker: INT. CAGE. LONDON ZOO. DAY
dialogues.text: Now she sits disconsolately in a corner of her permanent enclosure. She has been dressed, ridiculously and poignantly in a smock and a bonnet. A group of onlookers are trying to get a reaction out of her. Eventually they give up and move on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In London she had many admirers - of whom your father was but one. Darwin moves forwards from the shadows, where he has been observing and taking notes. As the other humans move away be attempts to start a conversation with Jenny in her own language, much in the way he communicated with baby Annie. DARWIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hoo hoo hoo hoo. Jenny regards him sceptically then looks away. DARWIN.

dialogues.speaker: HOO
dialogues.text: She startles and looks at him aggressively. DARWIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hm? He reaches in his pocket. This gets her interest. She com closer, expecting food. Darwin takers out a sprig of verbena - a strongly scented herb. He holds in front of his nose and inhales, making content expressions of pleasure. Jenny watches. Darwin holds the verbena towards Jenny. Cautiously she extends a hand through the bars. Their fingers touch in space, like God Giving life to Ada For Darwin its a breakthrough - a moment of connection. Jenny eats the verbena and spits it out, shrieking angril CHARLES

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wait, sorry, wait - I've got something else here for you He reaches in his pocket. She cocks her head, alert. With the air of a conjurer, he pulls out: A child's hand mirror, flashing as it catches the sun through the skylights. CHARLES

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pleasurable surprise) Ahhhh!! He shows Jenny her own reflection and, then hands the mirror through the bars. Jenny takes the mirror, bites it, discovers it is inedibl and smashes it on the ground. Charles makes a sad, whining sound CHARLES

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hew Hew Hew...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pouting)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hmph. Meaning: "OK then, I'm sorry." It's such a complex human reaction - grudging contrition that Charles laughs aloud with pleasure. Jenny laughs. Charles takes out a mouth organ and plays a snatch of Chopin. Jenny covers her ears and chatters. "Not listening not listening!" Charles, insulted, stops playing. Jenny laughs waves a hand as if to say: "Play, if it amus you. I'm must kidding."

dialogues.speaker: EXT. THE BEACH. THE PAST. DAY
dialogues.text: The salt wind. The dazzling light. The slow pulse of the surf. Darwin has paused in his narrative.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go on papa.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go on what.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The bit where she gets sick and dies.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. Why do you want to hear that bit?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I just like it. It makes me cry. Darwin smiles, his own eyes filling with tears. Then a door opens, softly, in the sky.

dialogues.speaker: INT. THE STUDY. THE PRESENT. NIGHT
dialogues.text: It opens wider to reveal Emma's elegant profile, framed against the gaslight of the hallway. Her POV: the black box is unlocked and open, its contents strewn around the floor at darwins feet. Darwin is sitting on the floor of the study holding in hi had a magazine, published by the Society for the useful Distribution of Knowledge, with a picture of Jenny on the cover EMMA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you coming to bed? DARWIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Presently. He doesn't move. She comes in EMMA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What did Huxley want? DARWIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He thinks I should write it and be done with it. He feels it is a question of moral courage ...or the lack of it. EMMA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You did not tell him about your health. DARWIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His theory is that I am making myself ill by holding back. That I should lance the boil. Plunge in and hang the consequences. EMMA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank the Lord he is not a surgeon. Darwin takes a breath and plunges in himself: DARWIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've concluded he is right. Bite the gag. Speed is everything. It will all be over in a matter of months. Emma is horrified. EMMA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is not mere months that concern me Charles. Nor even years or decades... Its said quietly but with genuine anguish. To Emma it is as though her life partner has announced he's contemplati suicide.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you really care   so little for your immortal soul   - for the knowledge that you   and I may never be together,   in all of eternity.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (softly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know that what concerns you concerns me also. What do think has held me in limbo all these years. Emma has. They both know it. She turns abruptly from the door and hurries away. 49   INT. BEDROOM. THE PRESENT. NIGHT. Emma has been crying. She lies in bed pretending to sleep Darwin gets into bed behind her. He wants desperately to reach out a hand to touch her, to comfort her, but he cannot do it for fear of weakening his own fragile resolv

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dearest Emma. You know This is not a decision made lightly....

dialogues.speaker: INT. DARWINS STUDY. THE PRESENT. DAWN
dialogues.text: In the dawn light, Darwin is writing a letter to his wife

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: .... It has been a very slow and gradual process, like the raising of continents. 51   EXT. GARDEN. THE PRESENT. DAY. EMMA stands alone in the wintry garden, a white apron ove her black dress, reading.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What else can I say to you, except that it seems the process is now complete. A tear tracks down the curve of Emma's cheek as she folds the letter, puts it in her pocket and return to the business of dead-heading flowers. In voice over we hear singing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All   things bright and beautiful, all   creatures great and small. All   things wize and wonderful, The   lord God made them all. 52   EXT. DOWN VILLAGE CHURCH . THE PAST. DAY. Move in through the graveyard, past the ancient yew..

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Each little flower that opens, Each little bird that sings, He made their glowing colors, He made their tiny wings. 53   INT. DOWNE VILLAGE CHURCH. THE PAST. DAY. The church is packed for the Sunday Morning service The Darwin family stand in the front row. Emma, the servants and the rest of the family are singing lustily: Parslow - a somewhat pompous operatic tenor, Brodie and Innes both loudly Scottish (Innes out of tune) Annie by Darwins side, trilling along in a tuneful little descant. She notices her father is not singing and offers him her hymn book with the words. Darwin smiles and returns it. Its not that he doesn't kno the lyrics, its just that he can't bring himself to say them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All things bright and beautiful all creatures great and small. All things wize and wonderful the Lord God made them all. The organ, played by Mrs Innes,   wheezes to a pause. Inn himself mounts the pulpit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let us pray. Everyone bows their heads in prayer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lord God we know the world is governed by Thy plan. Darwin is immediately not listening. He looks along the row of his children, standing dutifull in a line between Charles and Emma. George, aged 5, is studying the woodlice which are nestin between the pages of his hymnal

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Extending even to the merest creatures thou hast made, such that even a sparrow falls not to the ground without thy will. Darwin, stands watching the play of light from the staine glass window on his shoes. Then raises his head

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Teach us that all misfortune. All sickness and death, all the trials and miseries of which we daily complain are intended for our good, being not the vagaries of an uncaring universe but the corrections of a wize and affectionate parent Innes looks up sternly and sees the Darwin's head raised among the sea of down-turned heads. Their eyes meet briefly in a sort of challenge, and in th moment, Darwin somehow knows with absolutely certainty th religious faith has left him. With a whispered word to the beadle standing next to him take the collection Darwin slips out from the pew and hea off up the aisle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Excuse me He's intending to be quiet and subtle but the creaking boards under his feet loudly announce his departure. Innes raises his voice above the fusillade.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Turn with me now to the book of Job, Chapter Two verse twelve The congregation, not daring to raise their heads, watch Darwin's sturdy walking shoes departing down the aisle. 54   EXT. THE CHURCH. THE PAST. DAY. The rise and fall of Innes's voice continues in the background as Darwin walks out from the porch, emerging from shadow into sunlight. A summers day. He feels like a weight has been lifted. The church beadle comes out behind him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you all right, sir?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Never better. Thank-you. He heads off up the gravel path

dialogues.speaker: INT WOODLANDS. THE PRESENT. DAY
dialogues.text: The faint and Distant sound of church singing filters through the misty woods. The black wet trunks of trees catch the sunlight. Frosty dew highlights Mistletoe and holly and dead bracke and the sudden red flash of a robin. Darwin cuts a strange dark angular figure, walking along the narrow track a single step at a time. He pauses breathing, and listens. His quick eye catches the robin seizing a worm. Further on. A pheasant breaks cover. A hare stands uprigh in a clearing then bounds away. Darwin looks down and takes another step, placing his fee carefully, silently so as not to disturb the wildlife. Cut to a different pair of much newer shoes in exactly th same spot.

dialogues.speaker: INT. WOODLANDS. THE PAST. DAY
dialogues.text: Darwin is ten years younger, pacing in the same, measured way through summer woodland. There's a noise behind him and he turns, finger to his li for silence. Annie turns away from him and passes the sign down the li of children: Etty, George, Betty and Franky, in decreasin order of height.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shh

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to ANNIE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are we looking at? The question comes back up the line DARWIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A weasel. The children bunch up to gaze on a strange and wonderful sight. In a little sun-dappled clearing a weasel is turning loop the loops in a strange spiralling dance for the benefit of... ...a young rabbit, which sits utterly hypnotized by the performance. At first its strange and amusing, then the dance becomes more sinister. The weasel advancing by tiny increments as it tumbles in the air, finally ANNIE

dialogues.speaker: NO
dialogues.text: The weasel seizes the bunny rabbit by the back of the nec and shakes it savagely. The rabbit shrieks and spasms. Annie is beside herself, drumming the ground with her fee in a fever of fear and pity. The rabbit is still in its dearth throes, its neck broken its back legs still jerking ANNIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No! No! Stop it. Daddy. Stop it. Make it stop. The rabbit is already dead. DARWIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Annie, Annie, Annie. He sinks to his knees, heedless of the mud on his Sunday best worsted, embracing her. The others are shocked and amazed by the rabbits death, b none of them distressed as Annie. They are country childr and death is an everyday event GEORGE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The chickens do that too when cookie kills them ANNIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (tearful furious) Chickens are different! (To her father) (MORE) ANNIE (cont'd)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why didn't you do something. You should have stopped it!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The weasel has to eat. Its the way of the world. Annie

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Its not fair. Its not fair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, its not fair at all. Patting her and stroking her as the little sobs subside. The weasel is dragging the dead rabbit back to its lair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ....but still it is extraordinary, do you not think, that a weasel should learn to dance the polka. Despite herself the concept amuses Annie. Chest still heaving with sobs - she dries her eyes and smiles at him through her tears. 57   INT. DOWN HOUSE. BEDROOMS. THE PAST .NIGHT . Piano music - Chopin - plays softly over as Charles and Emma do the rounds of their large brood of children, turning out lamps and kissing sleeping heads, taking a do from one sleeping child's embrace, a sword from another. Shooing a cat and her kittens from the bedroom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good-night Lenny.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good-night Frankie

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good-night Betty. Darwin watches his wife, a sensuous figure, stooped over the sleeping child, a lock of hair falling forwards as sh kisses her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good-night George

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good-night Etty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good-night Willy

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good-night Annie She's sound asleep. Finally Charles and Emma are alone together in the blissfully silent house. Emma smiles

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dear Charles

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dearest Emma He takes her hand and leads her to their bedroom.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. THE BEACH. THE PAST. DAY
dialogues.text: Emma lies on a rug, her head is in Darwin's lap. She is reading aloud from a new book of poems by Wordsworth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Loving she is, and tractable though wild. And innocence hath privilege in her. To dignify arch looks and laughing eyes; And feats of cunning; and the pretty round Of trespasses, affected to provoke Mock chastisement, and partnership in play" She puts the book down

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smiling)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then we were wrong. She is not unique after all. Darwin is watching Annie dancing in front of the surf , turning cartwheels - a wild dancing sprite of the sea, oblivious to the cold, shouting and singing:

dialogues.speaker: THE BEACH. LATER
dialogues.text: Later, Near the cliff, Darwin is "geologising" He's excited, breathless and windswept, shouting over the sound of the nearby surf as he clambers over the huge assorted boulders pointing out the geological strata to h kids who are more interested in clambering. DARWIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is Devonian, about 400 million years ago. Rocks like this might have fishes in them, trilobites, tree ferns, corals maybe.... He knock off a corner of rock with his geological hammer, then moves on ETTY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is this a bit? DARWIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No that is Cretaceous Etty. It was made a hundred millions years ago, when this cliff was a coral reef and Down village was a swamp full of great crocodiles. Tap tap tap with his hammer as the boys scramble upwards, playing at mountaineers. DARWIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We might find oysters and sponges imprinted in it, or dinosaurs if we were lucky... GEORGE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's a dinosaur? ETTY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Professor Owen invented them. DARWIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They are the giant lizards which lived on earth before there were any humans. BETTY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But they weren't real DARWIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course they are, Betty. Did I never tell you of the skeletons I found in South America (to Etty) Do you remember Mr Martell? ETTY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. Annie arrives, hopping nimbly over the rocks still in her wet swimsuit

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes you do. When he came to tea and showed us drawings of his Iguanodon. And George burnt his fingers roasting chestnuts.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She doesn't remember.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You should have your clothes on Annie. You are quite blue.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Savages don't swear clothes. She runs to the top of a great fallen rock, spreads her arms out, and yells to the sky.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm a Fuegan.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well don't fall and hurt yourself. Your mother would never forgive me. Annie gives a shout and disappears head over heels.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Annie!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've found one! In the rubble at the base of the rocks she has landed, unhurt and quite by accident on a perfect specimen of a fossilized trilobite.

dialogues.speaker: INT. DARWIN'S STUDY. THE PRESENT. DAY
dialogues.text: The black box lies open with all its secrets strewn aroun the office. Stacks of paper - a stack for every chapter - are held do with paperweights - a fossil, a skull, a specimen bottle. Darwin squares a stack of blank paper between his hands, then reaches for his pen. 61   INT. VILLAGE SCHOOL. THE PAST . DAY. Annie reaches for her pen. Reverend Innes is giving the children their writing lessons, according to "Mulhauser's technique"

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: First positions. The children assume the position as if in some militarist drill.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Second positions. Grips are adjusted, pens are dipped.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Assume the distance. The children lean back fractionally, so their elbows are just back from the edge of the desk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: .....and begin. The Children start to copy the sentence which Innes has written on the blackboard. Annie reads the sentence and hesitates: "And on the seven day God ended his work which he had made; and he rested" 62   INT DARWIN'S STUDY. DAY. Darwin massages his cramped hand then takes a blank sheet of notepaper.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dearest Hooker. I am one week into the great project and I feel at last that it is real. Its title is "On the Origin of Species." As I write theses words why does it feel as though I am confessing to a murder... A paper stirs in the breeze and he pins it with the neare object to hand - Annie's trilobite. His eye rests on it a moment

dialogues.speaker: INT. DARWIN'S STUDY. THE PAST . DAY
dialogues.text: The corrugated gray surface, greatly magnified. The Darwin of ten years ago is examining the trilobite wi a watchmakers eyeglass. There is a small mirror above his desk, angled so as to give him a view of the path leading round from the front the house. Innes appears briefly in it, preceded by Annie, who is trotting to keep pace with him and crying. Darwin, intent on his work, notices neither of them From downstairs he hears the door knocker then Brodie's voice, then Emma's overlapping with half-heard fragments Innes's Scottish brogue.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I thought you needed to know why I had to chastised her. Darwin remains immersed, examining each detail of the trilobite, comparing it with other specimens in books and in boxes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ....It is not fair to the other nor to Annie herself that her head be filled with these ideas....

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you listening, Annie? Annie sobs louder, incoherent in her grief. Darwin finally focusses on the sounds, recognizes her distress and gets up to investigate. 64   EXT .UPPER HALLWAY. DAY. He reaches the top of the stairs. Annie is directly below him, slumped, still sobbing at the foot of the stairs. Emma has ushered Innes to the porch out of sight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I shall bid you good day then

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The front   door closes. Darwin comes downstairs

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What happened?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nothing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Its not nothing. (To Annie) Why are your knees bleeding? EMMA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr Innes had to have words with her. It is sorted now. DARWIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Words are very well. I am asking what happened to her knees. ANNIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr Innes sent me to the corner and made me kneel on rock-salt. DARWIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What! ANNIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (in a rush) I said there were dinosaurs and he said there wasn't dinosaurs but there were because you saw them. EMMA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (interrupting) Annie. Let me talk to your father. He told her to kneel til she repented... DARWIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Repented what? EMMA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The bleeding is due to her own stubborn-ness. It is finished now. DARWIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is by no means finished. Where is my coat. Its intolerable EMMA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Charles. Please. Charles ignores her, Forcing his arm into the sleeve of h coat. EMMA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr Innes is a dear friend and neighbor. I beg you at least appraise yourself the facts. She contradicted him repeatedly. The fault was Annie's Mr Innes was quite within his rights. DARWIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (his arm is stuck) In his rights to torture our children for expressing the plain truth. Brodie appears and Darwin ushers Annie towards her

dialogues.speaker: DARWIN EMMA
dialogues.text: ...Please take her to           It is not the truth as he kitchen.                        sees it DARWIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well damn how he sees it. Damn the pair of them and all their works EMMA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Charles listen to yourself. Listen Blocking his path as he heads for the door. Her palm flat on his lapel, soothing, reasoning with him DARWIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Emma please. I will not have Innes tell me what I can and cannot tell my children. EMMA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is what I have told them every night at bedtime. It is the instruction my aunt and your brother and most of our family live by. It is what all of the village believe ...or try to. Charles. Must our children be revolutionaries at nine years of age. Write to him with your concerns - our concerns - about the manner of the punishment but please do not set yourself against him. Think of my feelings on this. I beg you. Finally his outrage has spent itself, neutralized by her gentle persistence and the deep affection he holds for he DARWIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're right of course.... I'm sorry. He embraces her. Emma is reassured, she cannot see the conflict written al over Darwins face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The conflicted expression has hardened, the furrows in Darwin's brow etched deeper, as he dips his pen and begin the second chapter. From the floor below we can hear Emma practising a piece music on the piano - Chopin's revolutionary etude: a rippling, brooding arpeggio running up and down the keyboard, redolent of an angry sea. Darwin's pen scratches doggedly over the paper. 66   INT. BEDROOM. NIGHT. In the bedroom, in his nightgown, Darwin scrubs the ink stains off his fingers with a pumice stone. Emma passes behind him, preparing for bed. He glances at her in the mirror

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're still angry with me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. Why?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can always tell by your playing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not angry. I'm sad.

dialogues.speaker: INT. DARWIN'S STUDY. THE PRESENT. DAY
dialogues.text: Darwin sits at his desk, writing and editing, his hand clamped on the pen. A voice speaks from nowhere

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Talk to her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (still writing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And say what? She does not want to hear it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then write to her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (irritably)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That is what I am doing Annie, I am writing all of it.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. DARWIN'S STUDY. DAY
dialogues.text: Emma, passing the open door glimpses Darwin talking angri to himself as he writes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ....and then she can read it, and we can all be free of this! Now, please, Annie no more interruptions!

dialogues.speaker: EXT. GARDEN. DAWN
dialogues.text: The music continues, louder. A frosty coating of dew covers the lawn. Footprints lead to a strange wooden tower in the garden. Parslow stands outside, shivering in the grey morning light. Darwin shouts from inside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pull! Parslow pulls a lever. There's the sound of crashing water, a yell of pain from inside the tower. Ravens rise, calling, from the surrounding trees.

dialogues.speaker: INT. DARWIN'S STUDY. THE PRESENT. DAY
dialogues.text: Darwin dips his pen, scores out some text from his previo draft and writes again. The music continues from downstairs, louder and more insistent than before.

dialogues.speaker: LOUNGE ROOM. THE PRESENT. DAY
dialogues.text: Emmas hands race back and forwards along the piano keyboard.

dialogues.speaker: INT DARWIN'S STUDY. THE PRESENT
dialogues.text: Darwin's pen scratches across the pages, making a noise like fingernails on a blackboard. The music from downstairs seeming to drive into his skull He speaks aloud the words he is writing, in an effort to drown out the piano music.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... In time small variations become extreme...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Strange detailed drawings of barnacles are strewn across his desk, seeming to change and transmute before his eyes

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Organs change their very function, the oviduct becomes a cement gland.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He stops. His hand is shaking too much to write.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's an oviduct?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nothing that need concern you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sulkily) I know what it is anyway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Darwin gets up abruptly from his desk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pull!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Darwin stands naked, clutching to two hand rails for support as a great tub of freezing water tilts and pours its contents on top of him. Darwin yells

dialogues.speaker: EXT DOVECOTE
dialogues.text: Birds rush out from the dovecote

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Darwin dips his pen and writes

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ....What was once a free- swimming creature now finds itself glued by its head to a rock, flailing for food with its legs...,

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Revolutionary etude is continuous now - real or imagined.

dialogues.speaker: UNDER THE SEA
dialogues.text: Surf crashes. Underwater, among the swirling seaweed, fragile sea creatures being torn this way and that by the raging surf

dialogues.speaker: INT. MALVERN SPA TREATMENT ROOM. DAY
dialogues.text: Annie screams and kicks her legs, overwhelmed by water in some dark place. Pull back to reveal: 78   INT. HELL. A vision of hell: The water is fire. The barnacles are people. The people are Annie, Emma and Darwin.

dialogues.speaker: INT. BEDROOM. NIGHT
dialogues.text: Darwin wakes in a panic and sits up in bed. He raises his right arm and looks down at his inky writing hand fluttering in the moonlight, like an organ with a will al of its own Emma is a sleep. There's a crucifix on the wall above her bed. On the bedside table there's a bible.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: " ...About the midst of this valley I perceived the mouth of hell to be; and it stood also hard by the wayside. Now, thought Christian, what shall I do?

dialogues.speaker: INT. NURSERY. THE PRESENT. NIGHT
dialogues.text: The children are gathered around Emma who is reading a be time story to them by lamplight. Emma is in the centre of a circle of little attentive faces. She's aware of Darwin, standing in the darkened corridor beyond the door, drawn to the cosy little group but unabl to join it. She lets him be. Continues reading

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And ever and anon the flame and smoke would come out in such abundance with sparks and hideous noises, that he was forced to put up his sword, and betake himself to another weapon, called "All Prayer"..." 81   INT. ETTY'S ROOM NIGHT. The older girls Etty and Betty finish their prayers and jump into bed in their night-gowns Emma comes in to take away their lamp.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is Daddy not coming to kiss us good-night

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He is still a little bit ill from working ...maybe tomorrow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's what you said last night. Emma turns out the light. In the darkness Etty says.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think when Annie died he stopped loving us. Emma returns to her bedside

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh come now, Etty. You know that's not true. He is just a little bit ill - and a little bit busy.

dialogues.speaker: INT. BOILER ROOM. DAY
dialogues.text: In the bowels of Down House the house, we find Darwin wrapped in wet towels sweating in front of the wood-burni stove. As he gazes into the leaping flames, Annie appears at his shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is there really such a place as hell.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No of course not. How can there be? If he is supposed to be loving and forgiving - what on earth is the sense punishing all these millions of souls.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But just suppose if there was. And all this was punishment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All what? No reply.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know what you mean. All what?

dialogues.speaker: INT THE WATER TOWER. DAY
dialogues.text: Darwin stands, legs apart in the water tower bracing himself like a colossus against the full force of the deluge.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pull!

dialogues.speaker: EXT THE WATER TOWER. DAY
dialogues.text: The gardener, splitting logs, watches Darwin stagger from the tower with a rug wrapped around him, and make his way back to the house. 85   INT. DARWIN'S BEDROOM. DAY. Darwin lowers himself into bed, inky and tousled. He seem prematurely aged, crippled by the gruelling process of writing the book. As he lies there, unable to sleep lines of written text seems to appear behind his closed eyes, or in the tangled vines of the wallpaper. Emma speaks from the other side of the bed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Talk to Mr Innes. Please. You are clearly not well

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He is what? A physician now

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know what I mean. I think he can help you. Charles remains stubbornly silent, his hand fluttering ov the coverlet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am taking the children to Maer for a while, to visit their cousins. (Beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I worry for you, Charles. Please talk to him

dialogues.speaker: INT DARWIN'S STUDY. DAY
dialogues.text: Fire flares in the grate as Darwin compares the skeletons of various pigeons. He starts a new Chapter: "changes under domestication"

dialogues.speaker: INT. THE DOVECOTE. THE PRESENT. DAY
dialogues.text: Pigeons mate and coo in the dusty twilight.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. THE DOVECOTE. THE PRESENT. DAY
dialogues.text: Parslow picks up two of them, casually wrings their necks and heads off with them to the skeletonizing shed.

dialogues.speaker: INT. DARWINS STUDY. THE PRESENT. DAY
dialogues.text: Darwin Looks out of the study window, searching for inspiration. He sees Emma and the children getting into a coach with their baggage. 90   INT. DARWIN'S STUDY. THE PRESENT. NIGHT. Darwin sits at his desk. He has written the chapter heading and nothing else. Parslow knocks and looks in

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will you be eating sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No thank you. Parslow leaves. Darwin addresses the empty room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Annie? .....Annie. She will not come.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. THE BEACH. THE PAST. DAY
dialogues.text: Annie dancing in the surf. One minute she is there and th next she has vanished, lost among the churning waves. Darwin leaps top his feet shouting

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Annie! Raucous male laughter takes us to 92   INT. PUBLIC HOUSE. THE PAST. EVENING. The George and Dragon on a Saturday night. The air loud with laughter and thick with pipe smoke. Clodhoppers crowd the snug, many of them roaring drunk, with their florid complexions, stained and broken teeth. Darwin trying, to slip in discreetly is spied by a group locals who hail him and gather around him, wedging him in a corner with their overloud loud talk and laughter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr Darwin! Mr Darwin! I was explaining to Mr Goodman here your interest in breeding. Mr Darwin is our foremost scholar in the village.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. No I am but one of many. There is Squire Lubbock, and the reverend Innes The Thatcher waves them away as lesser talents.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ....he is also a noted explorer, the author of many books..

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...which no-one has read.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...a fellow of the Royal society and a prodigious expert on clams...oysters?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
