dialogues.text: Barnacles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr Goodman, now, is the foremost pigeon fancier in all the southern counties. Kent champion two years running. I swear he can give you any beak or plumage in four generations. Head and tail in five.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How do you do it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: By breeding cousin with cousin. I find it the fastest way to alter the strain - provided you do not weaken it in other ways. Darwin takes a slug of whiskey

dialogues.speaker: INT. DARWIN'S STUDY. THE PRESENT. NIGHT
dialogues.text: He is drinking in his office. The clock strikes twelve. The page in front of him remain stubbornly blank Darwin is rising from his desk when he sees something mov In one of the bottles on his desk, a fleshy marine specim seems to have come to life. It writhes blindly in its bottle of formalin, making a sound like a baby crying. Darwin, recoiling in horror, pushes himself back from his desk. The castors on his chair trundle back from his desk Behind him he hears a tapping and turns to see that all t birds in his big glass display case of Galapagos finches have started to beat against the inside the crowded glass case. They flutter, frenzied, tapping with their beaks on the inside of the glass, which shatters as... One by one the bottled specimens explode, discharging the contents onto the floor. A lamp falls over. The room is filled with birds the floo awash with formalin and broken glass. The Study seems to tilt like the cabin of a ship in a sto and.

dialogues.speaker: INT. DARWIN'S BEDROOM. THE PRESENT. DAWN
dialogues.text: Darwin wakes from the nightmare asleep at his desk, the whiskey bottle a quarter empty, ink on his hands and his shirt cuffs He gets up and puts on his shoes. 95   INT. DOWN HOUSE. DRAWING ROOM. THE PRESENT. DAWN . The scullery maid, lighting the fire, looks round and see Darwin. He walks past her without a word and heads out into the garden.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. DOWN HOUSE GARDEN. THE PRESENT. DAWN
dialogues.text: Darwin heads across the lawn, takes a key from his belt a opens the door of the skeletonizing shed.

dialogues.speaker: INT. SKELETONIZING SHED. THE PRESENT. DAWN
dialogues.text: In the grey light he takes in the corpses of doves from t dovecote. Some have been skinned, their pelts curing on frames, the carcasses steeping in a buckets chemicals which remove th flesh from the bones. Previously he regarded this place as a sort of laboratory Now it seems a place of horror. The door opens behind him. Its Parslow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get rid of them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Which ones sir?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All of them. All of it.

dialogues.speaker: INT. DOVECOTE. THE PRESENT. DAWN
dialogues.text: Darwin reaches into the dovecote and starts grabbing pigeons at random, dragging them out and flinging them in the air.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go. Go! 99    EXT. DOWN HOUSE. THE PRESENT. DAWN. Displaced doves beat the air. Darwin climbs down the ladder, grabs and axe and attacks the wooden stanchions supporting the dovecote Parslow comes running over from the skeletonizing shed, calling:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sir. Mr Darwin. Darwin stands back, hair wild, eyes crazed, his sleeves covered in bird shit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please rest sir. I'll have John Lewis remove it. Have some breakfast now and rest. Shall I call the doctor?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: God know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Or the water tower.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A pox on all of them!

dialogues.speaker: INT. ANNIE'S ROOM. THE PAST. DAY
dialogues.text: The local doctor Henry Holland takes out various concoctions from his medical bag and arranges them on the dresser. We are in the past. Annie is in bed with a fever. Emma is pregnant.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Calomel then, twice daily.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I will not give it to her. EMMA                             DOCTOR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Charles....                        Mrs Darwin, it is noth chloride of mercury. I have prescribed it often in children as young as two. DARWIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not to any of mine I hope. On the Beagle I dropped some on a microscope slide and all my animacules died of it. DOCTOR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well animacules are not persons. Presumably they would die if you dose them with Madeira wine. DARWIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On Madeira they thrived most excellently, as did Captain Fitzroy, while it lasted. Annie enjoys the joke and gives Darwin a weak smile. The doctor regards her balefully DOCTOR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Or if she would submit to be bled. ANNIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please no. DARWIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I will write to Dr Gully again. DOCTOR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sceptical) The hydro-therapist? DARWIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have always found his treatments most effective. DOCTOR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...no matter that they defy all sense of logic. He is packing up his bottles and his lancets DARWIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Logic is not everything. Emma shoots him a look. Til now scientific logic has been his guiding principle. DOCTOR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then I shall bid you good day. DARWIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Parslow will bring your carriage. I will be down presently The doctor leaves the room. Emma is in a terrible quandar

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I should take her to Malvern.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think it is better she is here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gully can care for her properly there. She can be treated daily, as I was.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Charles no. She is better with us. With her family. Please do not take her away from me.

dialogues.speaker: INT. DARWIN'S STUDY. THE PRESENT. DAY
dialogues.text: Parslow enters to find his master staring vacantly into space. The page in front of him is still blank. The study is in chaos. It seems as though the contents of the black box have multiplied and spread out to colonize every corner of the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Post for you sir. He leaves it by Darwins elbow and backs out. After a while Darwin seems to rouse himself. He picks up the largest envelope, postmarked Malaysia, an slits it with a letter knife. The sender is a Mr Wallace. There's a covering letter and twenty page attachment Darwin reads, and lets out a sudde loud bellow of laughter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ha!! 102   EXT. DOWN HOUSE. THE PRESENT. DAY. Darwin sits in sunshine at the rear of the house, rugged against the cold. Looking frail still, but oddly at peace

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ah, there you are Mr Darwin. Darwin looks up blinking in the sunlight to see the stock dark-suited figure of Mr Innes. INNES

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: May I join you. DARWIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: By odd means He makes some space on the bench. Innes hesitates, unable to read Darwin's feelings towards him. The smile is welcoming enough but there is something not altogether balanced about it INNES

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs Darwin informed me you would be alone and ....perhaps a need to counsel. He sees an envelope on the ground and stoops to retrieve it. INNES

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You dropped this. What a beautiful postage stamp. DARWIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. It is from the Spice islands. INNES

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I do rather envy your wide circle of correspondents. In my youth I always wanted to travel. DARWIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You are still young. You could be a missionary and follow in Mr Livingstone's footsteps. INNES

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, although I have always felt there is quite enough evil at home without looking for it abroad. (Then, casually) Mrs Darwin told me of the book you are writing. DARWIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not any more, thank goodness INNES

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You have finished it? DARWIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It has been finished for me. My correspondent In the spice islands has arrived independently at exactly the same idea, expressed in a mere twenty pages. (MORE) DARWIN (cont'd)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's brevity for you. I had so far covered two hundred an fifty and come to a dead end. So finally I am rid of the project. Innes is relieved to hear it INNES

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Lord moves in mysterious ways. DARWIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He does indeed Mr Innes. I was reflecting only the other day on the fact that he has endowed us in his blessed generosity with not one but nine hundred species of intestinal worm each with its own unique method of infiltrating the blood supply and burrowing through the mucosa. Innes shifts uncomfortably. DARWIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And then again on the great love he shows for butterflies by inventing a wasp to lay eggs inside the living flesh of caterpillars INNES

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well. It is not for us to guess at His reasons. DARWIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. We can leave that for Mr Wallace now. Should I advise him to stay overseas do you think? If he shows his face in Kent he may be required to kneel on rock salt. Innes rises. He's a short man, acutely aware of any threa to his dignity, and he's had enough of this mockery INNES

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I once valued our friendship Mr Darwin. I had hoped it might be possible to restore it. Clearly in your present mood that is not going to be possible. My regards to Mrs Darwin He starts off round the corner of the house. Darwin listens to his footsteps receding, then turns his face back to the sun. When he opens his eyes sees a figur standing in the lawn. It is Annie, plain as day, scowling at him angrily.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What? I am forestalled by Mr Wallace. That is the simple fact of it. What reason do you have to be angry?! She shoots him a look of hatred then turns away from him and runs off towards the meadow. Darwin, instantly remorseful, gets to his feet and hurrie after her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Annie! He reaches the centre of the lawn and stopped by a sudden intense pain in the gut which strikes him like a blow and fells him to his knees. He lies their gasping, his vision clouding as the pages o the Wallace letter slip from his grasp and are scattered the wind. A view from high above: spiralling downwards on the Darwi garden, as household servants emerge from various quarter and hurry to his assistance. 103   INT. DARWIN'S BEDROOM. THE PRESENT. DAY. There are some faint stains on the plasterwork of the bedroom ceiling. Like lichen on a rock. Like an archipela of islands. Darwin lies, pale and weak, looking upwards from a sea of white blankets. The door opens and he turns his head. Its Emma.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You have a visitor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. No. I will not be bled or lectured to. She gives him a pinched look, then Hooker pushes in behin her. HOOKER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is me. Thank God you are still with us. Word came from London you had suffered an apoplectic stroke. DARWIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. Simply the great relief of liberation. Did you read the Wallace abstract. Hooker bats the idea away HOOKER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is a letter. You have a book DARWIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...barely half of it HOOKER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You have a book. What is not already on the page is most certainly inside your head and I intend to extract it, if it kills us both. DARWIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You have been talking to Huxley. HOOKER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. Had I done so he would have hastened here himself armed with every instrument of torture known to her majesty's navy. (Then) Charles I have read the first Chapters. It is brilliant. You must continue. DARWIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I cannot. Seriously Joseph, I am completely blocked. All my old symptoms have returned with a vengeance. The sweats the shakes the abdominal pains. The whole endeavour was cursed from the outset. Hooker takes darwins hand, presses it to stop it from trembling HOOKER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Charles. It was you who opened my eyes to the wonders of science. So let me open yours. You have an illness. You have had it as long as I have known you. (MORE) HOOKER (cont'd)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is clearly made worse in times of overwork but the nature of the work is irrelevant. This is not visited on you by God or the devil. This is a set of physical symptoms. Go to Malvern and get treated.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not Malvern

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why not. What is there to be scared of there. He has worked for you in the past it will work again. Then come back and finish the book. Your enemies are already toasting their good fortune but they shall not prevail.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you talking about. I have no enemies.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They are legion, believe me, and they are implacable. We are all of us fighting a battle against fear and superstition but we can win this battle. We must win it. You can win it for all of us. Go to malvern, then come back and finish it. 104   INT. DOWN HOUSE. THE PAST. DAY. Upstairs, Servants are packing for a journey. The vigorous Darwin of the past moves swiftly from room t room, gathering his things. Hat and gloves, books, spectacles, papers. Emma, eight months pregnant, tries to keep up with him

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Charles, please reconsider

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Emma it is weeks now, months. She is getting worse, not better.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then I am coming with you. DARWIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You cannot come. How can you possibly come in your condition. EMMA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is not so far. DARWIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is two days by coach and train. Who will look after the others. EMMA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I do not care for the others. I care for Annie! Etty, coming apon then unexpectedly, hears this and is instantly heartbroken. EMMA is devastated by the slip but is presently too overwrought to retract it. DARWIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Leave us please, Etty. Parslow has gathered up Annie from her room and is carryi her downstairs, pale and sickly-looking, with Brodie fussing behind. BRODIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Make sure she is tucked in. Watch her shawl ANNIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't need to go. At the bottom of the stairs, Darwin takes Annie from Parslow's arms DARWIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The coach is outside. I will carry her from here. EMMA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Annie... ANNIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mama... She clasps Emma's hand. Darwin keeps heading for the door Emma holds fast to Annies hand and follows behind DARWIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You will see Mamma when you are better. Say goodbye now. Parslow holds the door open. The coach is at the Gate. Em stops on the threshold, unable to let go her daughters ha and suddenly deeply convinced that she is making a mistak here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wait. I am coming with you

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please, Emma

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wait there. She hurries back inside. Darwin makes a decision and head for the coach.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. DOWN HOUSE. DAY
dialogues.text: Down the patch and through the open gate with the servant following.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get aboard. Brodie

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shouts back)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mama! The garden gate clangs shut behind them. 106   INT. DOWN HOUSE STAIRWELL/ UPPER HALLWAY. THE PAST. Emma looks out of the upstairs window, realizes they plan to leave without her and hurries downstairs again.

dialogues.speaker: INT. COACH. THE PAST. DAY
dialogues.text: Charles bundles Annie inside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to the coachman)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go. Go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (calls)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wait!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go now!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mama!! The coach sets off. Emma runs to the gate calling desperately.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Charles. Please God. No. Annie!

dialogues.speaker: INT. COACH. THE PRESENT
dialogues.text: Charles, feeble and debilitated, levers himself into the coach with Parslow assisting and slumps back in the leath upholstery. Servants gather at the gate. Some of them tearful, not expecting him to return 109   EXT. STEAM TRAIN. THE PRESENT. DAY. A steam train comes charging past trailing plumes of blac smoke, striking sparks from the track with its wheels. 110   INT. CARRIAGE. THE PRESENT. DAY. The sickly Darwin of the present sits hunched and nauseou with Parslow sitting beside him with his suitcase on his lap. Every jolt of the train sends a spasm of pain through Darwin's guts. The people sitting opposite - a woman, a child, and a man regard Darwin in silence. Whatever he suffers from its no good and they are worried about getting infected with it They plunge into a tunnel. The carriage fills with smoke. Parslow gets up and tries to close the window but it won' budge. A burning ember flies inside and lands on Darwin's leg. Darwin is too weak to lift a finger. Parslow slaps the ember and extinguishes it. 111   EXT. STATION. MALVERN. The train wheezes to a halt. The doors open and the train disgorges its cargo of sick people, come to Malvern for treatment - a coughing child, a woman with one side of he face aflame with shingles - the halt the lame and the afflicted.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. HORSE AND CART. DAY
dialogues.text: Darwin sits in the back as the attendant drives them through Malvern.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell him not this way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (loudly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello there. Stop. Can we go by the other route

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Worcester Road is shorter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...by the low road.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He wishes to go by the other route.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (with a sigh)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As you will sir. He backs up the horses and turns the cart around

dialogues.speaker: INT. GULLY'S CLINIC. DAY
dialogues.text: Dr Gully is the chief physician at Malvern spa. His marbl tiled consulting rooms resound with the sound of rumbling pipes and dripping water. Darwin reclines on a leather couch, watching the watery play of light on the ceiling. A door opens and Dr Gully comes in, accompanied by two assistants. Gully is a small dapper man wearing an apron over his shi and tie. His trousers are tucked into calf-length Wellington boots. He greets Darwin cheerfully, effusively.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr Darwin, old friend. Mr Darwin. It has been too long I fear. Tut tut tut tut tut. What have we now what have we now? He clasps Darwin's hand, feeling his pulse at the wrist, then commands him to open his mouth GULLY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: tongue... Darwin shows him. MR GULLY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ugh. Shirt up. Let me feel your liver. Darwin untucks his shirt. Gully prods at Darwin's belly. Darwin winces. DR GULLY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pulse hectic, togue furred, liver tender and enlarged. Darwin's ink stained fingers speak volumes. DR GULLY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No doubt you have been exercising your brain every hour that God gave you. DARWIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was persuaded to write book. DR GULLY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Madness there are far too many of those already. Are you Sleeping? DARWIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Poorly. DR GULLY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I suppose never taking the 50C dilution of Chelidonium. DARWIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shakes his head) I had the gardener build a water tower. It no longer has any effect. GULLY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course not. Your gardener is not a hydrotherapist. What on earth possessed you ? DARWIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I feared I was dying. DR GULLY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh come come come. We shall not have that talk here. Half turning to his assistant, who is staking notes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A smart spinal scrub. Cold douche daily at 7.00. Wrapping in towels and sweating by the lamp. Then, to Darwin:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No red meat, no reading, no mental agitation of any kind. We shall soon have you right old friend, we shall have you right.

dialogues.speaker: INT. TREATMENT ROOMS. DAY
dialogues.text: Music over: Darwin sits in a deep metal bath while one of Gully's assistants scrubs his spine with a loofah.

dialogues.speaker: INT. DOUCHE. DAY
dialogues.text: Darwin stands in a shaft of light, grabbing onto the hand rails as the icy flood continues to crash down on his shoulders, splintering and fracturing in the shaft of light.

dialogues.speaker: INT. TREATMENT ROOMS. DAY
dialogues.text: Two assistants bind him tight in damp linen sheets, til h is immobilised like a cocoon, with his legs together and his hands by his side. They pick him up and lie him down, quite rigid beside another pod like creature, similarly swaddled, with a red face and a beard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr Darwin is it? Darwin nods, unable to turn his head, or make any gesture with his hands. The stranger continues to talk to him nonetheless.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: William Carter of Southampton. I read your Beagle account many years ago. Former naval man myself. What brings you here? Myself, a Bilious fever with blood per rectum, but I have every faith in Gully. The man is a miracle worker.

dialogues.speaker: INT. TREATMENT ROOM. DAY
dialogues.text: Darwin sits with a blanket draped over his shoulders, und the merciless glare of a heat lamp. Sweat pours off him and forms puddles at his feet. 118   EXT. TERRACE. DAY. A bright sunny day. Darwin, looking weak but purged, sits on the terrace, sipping a glass of foul-tasting mineral water and looking out over the stone houses, fields and valleys of Malvern. Gully sits with him, interviewing him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What action do you most associate with the symptoms. Eating? Strong emotion? Strenuous Excercise?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Does the exercise of memory count as an action.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Memory of what.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My eldest daughter. You remember her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course. Of course. You must accept there was nothing more we could do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know that. I know. A long, awkward silence, neither of them wants to recapitulate the events of Annies death.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You say you were writing about her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. It is a scientific text. But I had reached a point, beyond which it was impossible to progress. She had been my companion throughout. Now it seemed she was ahead of me in a place I could not follow. 72

dialogues.speaker: GULLY
dialogues.text: Of course. Plainly she is in heaven.

dialogues.speaker: DARWIN
dialogues.text: That is what my wife believes. It is a great consolation to her

dialogues.speaker: GULLY
dialogues.text: But not to you.

dialogues.speaker: DARWIN
dialogues.text: Emma and I have become ...divided on it.

dialogues.speaker: GULLY
dialogues.text: Does it affect your marital relations.

dialogues.speaker: DARWIN
dialogues.text: We have none ...to speak of.

dialogues.speaker: GULLY
dialogues.text: (a beat) Are you familiar with the writings of DeQuincy."There is no such thing known to the mind as forgetting."

dialogues.speaker: DARWIN
dialogues.text: I don't know what it means.

dialogues.speaker: GULLY
dialogues.text: He suggests we have thoughts which do not actually enter the realm of consciousness. Nervous fibres exist after all throughout the whole body. Is it not possible that certain primal feelings manifest in some physical way. Eczema. Boils. A fever. Might some blocked passion imitate a gall-stone? Or even manufacture one.

dialogues.speaker: DARWIN
dialogues.text: Well, until someone devises a machine to read nervous impulses, or a telescope to look inside the body I suppose we can only guess at it.

dialogues.speaker: GULLY
dialogues.text: We can Mr Darwin. We can look inside you. If you find yourself open to it, there is a way of seeing.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. STREETS OF MALVERN. NIGHT
dialogues.text: Darwin wanders the cobbled streets of Malvern, pausing occasionally to consult a hand-written address. It is starting to rain as, finally, he arrives at the address he is looking for. A substantial terraced house. Darwin descends a stone staircase to the imposing front door, and rings the bell. As he waits for an answer a woman appears, unseen in the rain streaked window above, observing him. Darwin rings again. A moment later the woman answers the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs St John?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr Darwin. Come in.

dialogues.speaker: INT. MRS ST JOHN HOUSE. NIGHT
dialogues.text: The room is large and hot, crowded with pot plants, and bric- a-brac. Various fringed lamp-shades, a dancing Shiv a framed picture of Lourdes, and some illustrations from the Tarot. None of this inspires Darwin with confidence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just leave your coat on the table. Sit down here. Show me your palm. The husky voice and the plunging decollete troubles Darwi who hesitates.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry. I'm confused. What is it you do exactly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I envision what's inside your belly, dear. That's what you wanted, isn't it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Envision how? When Gully described you I fancied some scientific instrument....

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Depends what you class an instrument. In more resistant cases I might use a pendulum... He frowns. She smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Its ten shillings for a reading by the way. In advance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well. I have a ten shilling note here in my wallet. He doesn't take it out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you can tell me the numbers on it we can begin. Mr St John' face hardens.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (coldly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm a professional lady Mr Darwin. I don't do party tricks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am a professional man. And I asking for no more than I ask of all my colleagues - a demonstration of competence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is you who are here to be tested, Sir, not me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then I am sorry to have wasted your time. He puts his jacket back on and heads for the door. 121   INT. HALLWAY. NIGHT. Mrs St John follows him. As he reaches for the doorhandle and opens it, she says:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's with you, you know that. Darwin turns.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your little girl. I saw her from the window standing at the top of the steps.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How dare you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pardon?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...prey on people's grief like this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have done no such thing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (furious)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you take me for an idiot? Clearly Gully has appraised you of my history.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I beg to inform you he did no such thing!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is chicanery of the very lowest order and I despise it utterly!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get out.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. THE HOUSE. DAY
dialogues.text: Darwin steps outside and she slams the door on him. Darwi continues to rant at the closed door, standing in the pouring rain without his umbrella. He gets to the top of the steps, and looks around, trying to get his bearings. In a pool of lamp-light at the far end of the street a figure stands watching him. Darwin squints at her through the rain, which is falling harder now. The figure is Annie. She looks at him crossly, then heads off up a cobbled sid street. Darwin follows.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. MALVERN. SIDE STREETS. VARIOUS. NIGHT
dialogues.text: Darwin pursues his daughter up narrow cobbled lanes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Annie. Annie! The rain is getting heavier, turning the gutters into rivers. Water overflows the drains and culverts and rushes over t cobbles, making them slick and treacherous. Darwin hurries down darkened lanes and alleys, the sound rushing water echoing all around, the little girl always ahead of him. A DRUNK MAN in oilskins comes barreling past him, head down, cursing the weather. A child's ball goes floating downhill in the current. Darwin loses Annie, then he sees her again, at the top of steep flight of stone steps. Darwin, drenched chases after her. 124   EXT. WORCESTER ROAD. NIGHT. At the top of the steps he stops for breath and he looks around. There is no sign of Annie but he knows this street - The Worcester Road - a row of Grey Georgian houses, their bac against the hill, their sloping front gardens looking out over the rooftops of Malvern. Most of the street is in darkness but the house directly opposite has lights in the window. He knows this house also. He hesitates, then crosses the street towards it.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. GUEST HOUSE. NIGHT
dialogues.text: Soaked to the skin, he raps with the brass door-knocker, then waits for someone to answer. Muffled voices. Then a man answers from within.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is Mrs Carey still the landlady here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. The door opens on a chain.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My daughter Annie ...lodged here some years ago. Can I come in? The man closes the door to release the chain, then opens again to admit Darwin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know this is an intrusion. I wonder - could I visit the room she stayed in? The landlord doesn't know what to make of this

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wait here. I'll get the missus. He leaves Darwin dripping in the hallway which he goes an consults with his wife in the lighted parlour. Darwin looks around. This place is all too familiar to hi the bevelled gold-rimmed mirror, the carved mock-Tudor co stand. Muffled conversation off. There are crutches and walking sticks among the umbrellas Lavender potpourri in a brass dish. A wheel-chair in one corner, a picture of the pieta above the door. Finally, the land-lady emerges from    her parlour.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Which room?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fourteen. I would only be there ten minutes. I am happy to pay. She goes into an alcove and emerges with a key.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Up one flight and along the corridor to the right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I remember.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Try not to touch anything. 126   INT. GUESTHOUSE. THE PRESENT. NIGHT. Darwin, climbs the stairs to the Landing.

dialogues.speaker: INT. GUESTHOUSE. THE PAST DAY
dialogues.text: The younger Darwin flees up the stairs. 128   INT. GUESTHOUSE. THE PRESENT. NIGHT. The older Darwin, reaches the top of the stairs and walks along the corridor to the right.

dialogues.speaker: INT. GUESTHOUSE. THE PAST DAY
dialogues.text: The younger Darwin, races along the corridor. 130   INT. GUESTHOUSE. THE PRESENT NIGHT. The older Darwin, hesitates, chest pounding, outside the door of number 14, then unlocks it as...

dialogues.speaker: INT. GUESTHOUSE. THE PAST. DAY
dialogues.text: The younger Darwin bursts into room 14 and takes in the scene. The room is full if light. A maid is bundling soiled sheets. Brodie is there with a harrassed-looking Dr Gully They turn as he enters. Annie lies on the bed between them, her breathing fast an shallow. She manages a weak smile.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is she any better? Does she want for anything? Gully stands up from the bed. His expression tells us hop is fading. Annie's pale sunken cheeks and caked lips confirm it. Darwin kneels by her bedside, clasps her little hand is h own.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Darling Annie. I am here now. Annie lets out a reedy whine of appreciation and strokes his lapel "making him beautiful" Brodie cannot bear it and bursts into tears. 132   INT. ROOM 14. THE PAST NIGHT. Annie sleeps. Darwin sits up, writing to Emma, crying as he writes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dearest Emma. I think it best for you to know how every hour passes. It's a relief for me to tell you. Whilst writing to you I can cry tranquilly. 133   INT. ROOM 14. THE PAST DAY. A local surgeon lays out various instruments, including a glass syringe with a long needle. Annie struggles and whimpers. Brodie comforts her

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr Coates the Surgeon came today to draw off Annie's water. This did not hurt her, but she struggled with surprising strength against being uncovered.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There there. It will all soon be over.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. CHURCH AT MALVERN. ENTRANCE. DAY
dialogues.text: Darwin enters through the heavy stone entrance.

dialogues.speaker: INT. THE CHURCH AT MALVERN. DAY
dialogues.text: The relatives of the sick, stand or sit among the pews, arriving, praying, departing Darwin kneels awkwardly in front of the altar, clasps his hands together and prays:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Save her. I will believe whatever. Forever. Please save her He looks up at the image of Christ on the cross, hoping against all reason, for some sense of epiphany. It's not working. He feels nothing embarrassment at the cheapness of the gesture.

dialogues.speaker: INT GUEST HOUSE. ROOM 14. THE PAST .NIGHT
dialogues.text: Darwin sits alone with Annie who is babbling incoherently He can't make out anything she says

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Our dear child has taken a turn for the worse. She talked a great deal but we could seldom make out anything. Much of what she says we cannot make out from the roughness of her poor mouth.

dialogues.speaker: INT. GUEST HOUSE. ROOM 14 NIGHT
dialogues.text: Dr Gully leaves, the surgeon arrives. The maids squeeze between the two medical men, bundling sheets

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Today she vomited rather much again. Dr Coates has been to draw off more water. Brodie and the maid roll Annie on her side and cut off th tail of her shirt, then roll her on her back again, with pillow between her two bony knees.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is that good, my lovely

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (suddenly lucid)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Beautifully good. I am making custards.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gully thinks her in imminent danger. 138   INT. DOWN HOUSE. DAY. Heavily pregnant Emma sits in the drawing room, crying an reading Darwin's latest letter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We sponged her with water and vinegar, made her sweet with chloride of lime....I fear we must prepare ourselves for the worst 139   INT. ANNIE'S ROOM. GUEST HOUSE. DAY. It is midnight Darwin, exhausted, keeps a lonely Vigil by Annie's bedside. Each breath seems like it will be her last. Suddenly she speaks: faintly but audibly:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The rabbit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The rabbit taught him the polka.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't understand my love.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell me about Jenny. Darwin bends low to hear her more clearly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What about her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When she died

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't want to talk about death my love.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But tell me. I like it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well. What the keeper told me was. When she was very sick with pneumonia, lying very still, he tried to feed her but she shook her head, looking at him as though to say: "Its nice of you but really you shouldn't bother". And as he bent down to take the spoon away she brought her arms around his neck and kissed him. And then she was dead. Annie smiles, puts her hands around her fathers neck and dies.

dialogues.speaker: INT. TRAIN THE PAST DAY
dialogues.text: Darwin sits, his face wet with tears, reading, through blurred vision, a letter from Emma.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was in the garden looking at our poor darling's little flower bed when John Griffiths drove up with your letter.

dialogues.speaker: INT. DARWIN'S BEDROOM. NIGHT
dialogues.text: Emma goes to bed, utterly drained.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When I went to bed I felt as if it had all happened long ago. When the blow comes it wipes out all that preceded it. 142   INT. DARWIN'S BEDROOM. DAY. She opens the curtains on a bright day. The other childre are playing in the garden

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My feeling of longing for our lost treasure makes me feel painfully indifferent to the other children, but I shall get right before long.

dialogues.speaker: INT. TRAIN CARRIAGE. THE PRESENT. DAY
dialogues.text: Darwin sits in the train, Heading home from malvern. He is looking across the carriage at his younger self, re reading the letter and weeping uncontrollably.

dialogues.speaker: EXT DOWN HOUSE. LOUNGE. THE PRESENT. NIGHT
dialogues.text: Torrential rain crashes down on the house, the garden, th ancient trees and the outbuildings, flooding the path and the lane beyond the gate. Darwin pays the coachman and hurries inside 145   INT. DOWN HOUSE. LOUNGE ROOM. Emma is playing a beautiful slow Nocturne. The rain outside drown out all other side. She doesn't notice the figure of Darwin until he appears, like a ghost, reflected in the polished wood of the piano She turns with a start and sees him, still in his drippin coat, hair plastered over his brow

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry. I startled you. EMMA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Take your coat off by the fire there. What time is it? Darwin stays where he is, dripping on the carpet DARWIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We need to talk. I need to talk to you. EMMA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course, but dry your hair. I shall call for a towel. As she moves to the bell-pull he grabs her wrist DARWIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I went back to Worcester Road. I saw Annie. EMMA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Charles. No. DARWIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let me tell you. EMMA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't want to hear it. This must stop. DARWIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't understand. EMMA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I do! Do you think me deaf and blind. You have lived with her and spoken with her every day since she died. Parslow comes in with firewood then sees Emma yelling at darwin and hurriedly retreats, spilling logs in the hallway. EMMA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She is more real to you than I am. She's dead Charles. DARWIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know that. EMMA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then what is wrong with you that even our poor daughter cannot be left in her grave but you would.... DARWIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know she is dead. I know it. It is you who will not accept the fact, preferring to think of her in heaven. This again! The unspoken argument which has been brewing for a decade, never before expressed so bluntly. Emma hea for the door EMMA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get away from me! She heads into the hallway, he follows her ranting DARWIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Snowy white wings and dancing with the angels. Is that your idea of honesty. Servants scramble out of sight and out of earshot EMMA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why did you come back. I will not hear this! Emma picks up her skirts and hurries up the stairs. Darwi pursues her. On the landing, Betty and Horace, wide eyed and terrified are bundled into the nursery by Brodie as Charles thunder up the stair. DARWIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You have to Emma, everything these was between us is gone. The boat is wrecked and sunk now. We have to hold to something else. EMMA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To what. Your ghosts? Your theories? What Charles. CHARLES

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To the truth of what we know it. She slams the bedroom door on him and bolts it. DARWIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Open this door Emma. The truth, how wonderful and extraordinary our daughter was.... EMMA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (through the door) I know that. I do not need you to say it. Of course I know. Charles throws his shoulder to the door and bursts throug it. Emma screams CHARLES

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But free of the fantasy, free of the rest, the silly vain hope that we will be reunited in heaven and the nagging unspoken belief that I killed her! In the lower hallway all the servants hear this In the nursery, Brodie, aghast, covers the childrens ears In the bedroom, Emma has nowhere left to run EMMA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have never said that CHARLES

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Say it now. Say it. And all the rest that follows. That I should have kept Annie warm that day on the beach. I should not have taken her to Malvern. I should have let you come. Tears spring to her eyes and to his. The fury has gone fr both of them, leaving sadness and pity EMMA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I should have insisted. CHARLES

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. It was me. I took her from you It was my fault. EMMA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I could have followed. I was her mother what was I thinking of. CHARLES

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We thought she would live. You were not to know. He moves to her, she startles, then lets him enfold her i his damp coat EMMA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I did. I did know. I knew when you left that I would never see her again. I hated you for taking her. CHARLES

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I hated myself. I knew that none of them could save her. (MORE) CHARLES (cont'd)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All I could do was watch hopelessly and weep for her - then flee the place in terror, not even waiting to see our poor dear daughter buried. She was our treasure and I failed her. We both did. We should never have married each other.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you saying?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The unspeakable . I am saying that you and I, in making our perfect child, endowed her with the very weakness which killed her. Emma. That is what I couldn't write. That is what forestalled me all these years. It wasn't you I was angry with, it wasn't Innes and it wasn't God. I was angry with my theory. It was the truth I was angry with. It is the truth. Weeping, she shakes her head in furious denial. He kisses her hair, her eyes, her tear-streaked cheeks...

dialogues.speaker: INT/ EXT BEDROOM, THE PRESENT. NIGHT
dialogues.text: Rain continues to batter the house outside Inside Darwin and Emma make love, with a kind of wild desperation, their clothes strewn all over the floor, clinging to each other like castaways in a storm.

dialogues.speaker: INT OFFICE. THE PRESENT. DAY
dialogues.text: Darwin enters his office. The chaos that existed here previously has been tidied away into files and boxes. Darwin opens the black box, takes out the files, places them on his desk, then sits down and begins to write 148   INT. STUDY. NIGHT. Darwin sits at his desk. Writing. He is possessed of a ne sense of calm and purpose, the pen gliding fluently acros the page. Night turns to day and then to night again. Darwin completes the Chapter headed "variation under domestication" and begins on a fresh sheet of paper.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. THE GARDEN. DOWN HOUSE. THE PRESENT. DAY
dialogues.text: Crocuses are pushing up through the flower beds. Tiny gre buds have started to emerge from the dead black branches

dialogues.speaker: INT. DARWIN'S STUDY. DOWN HOUSE. THE PRESENT. DAY
dialogues.text: Still Darwin writes

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell me a story.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm busy Annie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (petulantly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll go away again, then you'll be sorry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right, come here, come here. She comes and sits on his lap.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Once there was a man Who, while travelling in South America, came apon a beautiful and dangerous idea.

dialogues.speaker: INT. SOUTH AMERICAN JUNGLES. DAY
dialogues.text: Darwin is in the south American jungle, trying to coax do from the trees, some small squeaking creature - a tousled looking abandoned chick.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here, here. Come on, come on then The creature draws closer, eyes like gimlets in the dark foliage.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...I wont hurt you. He reaches into the dark recesses of the forest. Darwin grabs it and stuffs it, squawking into his collecting bag

dialogues.speaker: INT. DARWIN'S STUDY NIGHT
dialogues.text: Darwin comes in, empties the bag into a black box with perforations and closes the lid

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He knew his wife wouldn't care for this creature so when he came home he locked it in a box, where it couldn't run around and do any damage.

dialogues.speaker: INT. DARWIN'S STUDY. DAY
dialogues.text: Darwin works at his desk. There's a plaintive cooing soun coming from the box next to his feet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But every so often he'd open the lid and feed it, just because he couldn't bear to let it die. Finally he opens the lid and offers the creature a biscui It has grown a bit larger and made itself a nest. It take the biscuit and peeps gratefully.

dialogues.speaker: INT. DOWN HOUSE. DAY
dialogues.text: Darwin goes to the box and opens it. There's nothing ther but an empty nest and some broken eggshells.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One day he opened the box and discovered it wasn't in there at all. It had escaped with all its babies, who were nesting all over the house making a terrible mess.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Darwin's, their children and their servants run aroun the house finding birds everywhere. There is bird-shit on the curtains and the antimacassars, birds nesting in the sewing basket, the bread bin and the dress-up box. Every time you open a cupboard, angry birds fly out and flap angrily around the room. Mayhem. The house is in uproar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But finally they caught them all, and bundled them in a blanket and he asked his wife to dispose of them as she saw fit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Annie listens entranced. Darwin pauses

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And what did she do?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know but I fancy she took them out in the garden and set them free. 157   EXT. DOWN HOUSE. GARDEN DAY. Emma and Brodie come out carrying a huge white linen bag between them. They shake it out in the garden and birds come pouring ou of it. High shot, looking down on EMMA as she watches the birds wheeling round and round in the sky above.

dialogues.speaker: INT. DARWIN'S STUDY. DAY
dialogues.text: Darwin sits in his study window, watching a great flock o birds wheeling in the sky outside, the whole flock formin an ever-changing shape from the movement of its tiny component parts.

dialogues.speaker: INT DARWIN'S STUDY. NIGHT
dialogues.text: Darwin puts down his pen, waking, as if from a dream. The manuscript is finished. The music of Chopin filters up from downstairs.

dialogues.speaker: INT. DRAWING ROOM. DAY
dialogues.text: Emma is playing by candle-light. Darwin places the manuscript on top of the piano. She stops abruptly. The last chord resonates in the musky air.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Done. I have finally got it out of the air and into these pages. Will you read it and decide what must be done with it. I confess I no longer know and I am very tired. She takes his hand and squeezes it. 161   INT. DOWN HOUSE. BEDROOM. Darwin undresses.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Emma sits at the table and begins to read.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Darwin gets out of the bath and towels himself dry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Emma lights a candle from the one before and continues to read. 165   INT. DOWN HOUSE. BEDROOM. NIGHT. Charles lowers himself into the bed, sleep washes over hi like a wave. 166   INT. DOWN HOUSE. DINING ROOM. NIGHT. Still Emma reads.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thus, from the war of nature, from famine and death, the most exalted objects we can conceive directly follow. There is a grandeur in this view of life ...in which endless forms most beautiful and wonderful have been and are being evolved. Outside the sky is growing lighter. 167   INT. DOWN HOUSE. BEDROOM. DAY. Charles wakes. He opens the curtains on a clear autumn day. The house is unusually quiet. 168   INT. DOWN HOUSE. TOP OF THE STAIRS. DAY. The grandfather clock on the landing strikes mid-day. Darwin goes downstairs. 169   INT. DRAWING ROOM. DAY. He enters the drawing room. There is no sign of Emma nor his manuscript. He goes to the window and sees her at the bottom of the garden standing over a bonfire, burning something. 170   EXT. GARDEN. DOWN HOUSE. DAY. Darwin goes outside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Emma? She looks up from the fire. Darwin crosses the lawn to he She's burning leaves and dead-heads from the flower garde

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you read it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And....

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wrapped it and put it on the table there. There's a brown paper parcel on the garden table where th like to sit under the big Cyprus tree. Darwin picks it up, it is addressed to John Murray, Publisher, stamped and sealed with sealing wax.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're right. True or not it must all be said. Probably most of it is true. God help us. Darwin kisses her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Careful. I have soot all over my hands. 171   EXT. BOTTOM OF THE DRIVE. Darwin stands with the brown paper package, turning it ov in his hands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dear Hooker, I have today despatched to John Murray the completed manuscript. Who knows if anyone will buy it and how they will respond. No doubt many will wish al diabolo altogether. But least it is out in the world now and no longer torturing me. John Griffiths, the postman, comes up the hill from the village. Darwin gives him the manuscript. The Postman puts it in h satchel and heads on up the lane. Darwin turns back and walks up towards the house. As he does so a little figure, Annie takes his hand, and together they continue on home, Annie skipping happily by her father's side. 172   POST-SCRIPT. Darwin's "Origin of Species" was sold out on its day of publication. A classic to this day, it was reprinted six times before his death; and his burial, with full Christian honours, i Westminster Abbey.
